reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Saying "1 bundle" and "2 bundle" takes too long, so you decide to call these bundles what they look like: わ for <reading>wa</reading>lrus (わ)!
The reading for 駄 is the secondary kanji reading. Instead of だ it's た. Hopefully you've heard of "geta" before. This will make it really easy for you to remember the reading of this vocab word.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, x2 with a しい added on for good measure.
Personally, I look up to the color <reading>青</reading> (あお). Literally and figuratively. I love the color blue, so I look up to it and respect it. Also, I look up at the sky and it's blue.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the はく reading you learned with the kanji.
The reading for this word is an exception. But you already learned the 叔母 which means aunt too. Well they have the same reading! So if you know one aunt, you know them all.
The reading for this word is an exception. But you already learned the 叔父 which means uncle too. Well they have the same reading! So if you know one uncle, you know them all.
The reading for the 仰 portion is an exceptional one. Instead of ぎょう it's こう. Just remember, when it comes to religious faith, all you need to believe in is <reading>こう</reading>いち.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>Occasionally</vocabulary> <reading>Tama</reading>ra (たま), the local ball girl, will take a break from her duties. But it's really only once in a while, because Tamara is such a hard worker.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading is like the reading of 包み, which means "bundle" or "package." Try to think of an <vocabulary>embankment</vocabulary> that's made purely from bundles and packages. These <reading>包み</reading>(つつみ) are the only thing holding the water in!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading for 宮 is one you haven't seen before. Just think about how <reading>cu</reading>te (きゅう) this imperial court is. It's a My Little Pony imperial court, or something.
The reading comes from 尽きる.
Look up at the <vocabulary>summit</vocabulary>. It's such a <reading>mean</reading> (みね) summit. So big, so stormy, so mean.
Remember 旨い, which means "delicious"? Remember how it also means "skillful" and "clever"? It's the same with this word, and the reading is the same as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading has いろ (like 色) in it, then a ど, so think about an <reading>色 do</reading>g, running around coloring things, because that's what an 色 dog does.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading comes from 悔しい.
The reading is 悪い and 賢い combined together into one word. Be careful of the rendaku.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

These are both the kun'yomi readings, but you haven't learned this for 原 yet. It's actually the rendaku'd version, so let's just use a mnemonic to remember it instead:

You know you're in a <vocabulary>mulberry field</vocabulary> when you see a bunch of capy<reading>bara</reading>s (ばら) rolling around in there with you. Capybaras love mulberries! Picture a whole family of capybaras munching on mulberries. Mm Mmm!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The readings come from 殴る and 合う, punched together.
The reading comes from the word 殴る and the kanji 込.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

<reading>Hoe Ra</reading> (ほら), the version of Ra who carries a hoe around, is using said hoe to dig out a <vocabulary>cave</vocabulary> for himself, to provide shade from the sun (despite being the god of sun). He digs digs digs and then sits in his nice cave, hoe in hand.

The reading of 洞 is one you've learned. The reading of 穴 isn't one you've learned, though. So, think about how you go inside this <vocabulary>cave</vocabulary>, only to find yourself covered by some red goopy liquid. You think it's blood, but luckily it just turns out to be <reading>ketsu</reading>p (けつ). If you want to be less formal, you can also use the kun'yomi and say ほらあな, but then you'd never learn that reading for 穴, and where's the fun in that?
The reading is 淀 plus 川. Be careful of the rendaku.
The reading comes from 溶かす.

You're going <vocabulary>to drift</vocabulary> away. Drifting drifting drifting. Then, you turn into a yo-yo and yell "<reading>ta-da yo</reading>-yo (ただよ)! Not sure why drifting turns you into a yo-yo, but imagine it and don't question it.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Who wanted the candle <vocabulary>to be lit</vocabulary>? <reading>Tom</reading> (とも) Cruise. He's afraid of the dark so he always wants all the lights and candles in the house to be burning at all times.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji. Good for you!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the rendaku.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

For something <vocabulary>to billow</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to flutter</vocabulary>, you'll need to ask the <reading>here guy</reading> (ひるがえ) - that's guy who's here right now - to open the window and let in the breeze.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
I'm going <vocabulary>to threaten</vocabulary> you with your life if you have a bad <reading>odo</reading>r (おど). Imagine someone with a bad odor, then threaten them.

The reading for 興奮 is one you didn't learn with the kanji, though it's similar. Instead of きょう it's こう, so just think of how whenever you feel excitement, it's thanks to <reading>こう</reading>いち. So just think of こういち exciting you in some way to remember this vocab's reading.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. But you knew that already, didn't you?
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
You need <vocabulary>to consult with</vocabulary> a <reading>hacker</reading> (はか) to solve your hacking problem. Imagine consulting with a hacker, whatever a hacker looks like in your mind.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This shares a reading with 蓄える, which makes sense, as the meanings of them are very close to each other! If you’re not sure you remember the reading, here’s the mnemonic once more to help you remember it:

You need <vocabulary>to save</vocabulary> up things, so you <reading>take one</reading> (たくわ) and put it aside, then take one more and put it aside again. Repeat this process of taking one over and over and you’ll quickly <vocabulary>save up</vocabulary> lots of things.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading comes from 輝く.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
Everything you've accomplished can be stored in your single little pinky <reading>toe</reading> (と)... you haven't accomplished that much, apparently.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

This is a long reading for such a short word! Think of something being <vocabulary>wicked</vocabulary>. <vocabulary>Evil</vocabulary>, even! But what is wicked? It's the side of the island... but only the side. It's the <reading>横島</reading> (よこしま).
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second. Luckily, you've learned them both already so you should be able to slap them together and know the reading of this word!

Strangely, the reading for this word is the same as the vocab reading of 風 (かぜ). That's probably going to be the easiest way to remember this, especially since otherwise the reading would be one big horrible exception.
The reading comes from 飢える.
The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of the shortening of 鬱 or you'll feel gloomy.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the shortening, and don't be tricked by the hiragana sticking out. The readings of the kanji don't change.
The reading is a reading you've known your whole life. It's like you were born with the reading, whispering in your ear, ready to emerge at just the right moment... and that moment is now.
The reading is the individual vocab readings of 麻 and 布 combined together.
